question: [File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-compiler-v2/src/pipeline/lint_processor.rs] [Function: process()] [Bypass vulnerability] Can an attacker craft a malicious Move module that marks security-critical functions as native (line 31-32) to bypass all lint checks, potentially allowing vulnerable code patterns to be compiled and deployed on-chain? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-compiler-v2/src/pipeline/lint_processor.rs] [Function: process()] [Access control bypass] Does the is_primary_target() check (line 35-37) properly validate module ownership, or can an attacker manipulate module metadata to mark malicious dependency code as non-primary to evade lint scrutiny while still getting compiled? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-compiler-v2/src/pipeline/lint_processor.rs] [Function: process()] [State corruption] After running linters (lines 38-41), the original FunctionData is returned unchanged (line 42) - can race conditions between multiple concurrent process() calls on the same FunctionTargetsHolder lead to inconsistent checker execution or skipped security validations? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-compiler-v2/src/pipeline/lint_processor.rs] [Function: process()] [Type confusion] The FunctionTarget is created from func_env and data (line 34) - can malformed FunctionData cause the FunctionTarget constructor to create an inconsistent state where subsequent checker invocations operate on corrupted bytecode? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-compiler-v2/src/pipeline/lint_processor.rs] [Function: process()] [Resource exhaustion] If get_applicable_linter_pipeline returns an extremely large number of checkers (line 38), can this cause unbounded iteration (lines 39-41) leading to compilation timeouts and denial-of-service against the Move compiler? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-compiler-v2/src/pipeline/lint_processor.rs] [Function: process()] [Panic safety] If any lint.check() call panics (line 40), does this leave the FunctionTargetsHolder in an inconsistent state, potentially corrupting subsequent compilation passes or causing compilation of partially-validated unsafe code? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-compiler-v2/src/pipeline/lint_processor.rs] [Function: process()] [Early return bypass] The early returns for native functions (line 32) and non-primary targets (line 36) occur before checker execution - can attackers exploit this ordering to inject malicious code in dependencies that gets executed but never validated? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-compiler-v2/src/pipeline/lint_processor.rs] [Function: process()] [Missing validation] The _scc_opt parameter (line 29) for strongly connected components is unused - could circular function dependencies in malicious code bypass lint checks due to lack of SCC-aware processing? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-compiler-v2/src/pipeline/lint_processor.rs] [Function: process()] [Concurrent modification] The _targets parameter is mutable but unused (line 26) - could other processors running concurrently modify the FunctionTargetsHolder while linters are executing, causing time-of-check-time-of-use vulnerabilities? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-compiler-v2/src/pipeline/lint_processor.rs] [Function: process()] [State leakage] The FunctionTarget created on line 34 borrows data - if checker.check() stores references to this target internally, could dangling references persist after process() returns, leading to use-after-free in subsequent pipeline stages? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-compiler-v2/src/pipeline/lint_processor.rs] [Function: get_applicable_linter_pipeline()] [Options injection] The Options extension is retrieved via expect() (line 59) - if an attacker can control the GlobalEnv extensions, can they inject malicious Options with crafted external_checks to execute arbitrary code during lint processing? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-compiler-v2/src/pipeline/lint_processor.rs] [Function: get_applicable_linter_pipeline()] [Early return vulnerability] If options.external_checks is empty (line 60-62), an empty vec is returned - can attackers craft compilation environments where external_checks is deliberately empty to bypass all security lint checks? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-compiler-v2/src/pipeline/lint_processor.rs] [Function: get_applicable_linter_pipeline()] [Name collision attack] The known_checker_names (line 63) are compared against lint_skips (line 72) - can an attacker register malicious checkers with names matching legitimate security checkers to shadow and disable real security validations? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-compiler-v2/src/pipeline/lint_processor.rs] [Function: get_applicable_linter_pipeline()] [Filter bypass] The filter on line 72 checks if lint_skips.contains(&lint.get_name()) - can an attacker exploit Unicode normalization issues or case sensitivity bugs to craft skip directives that don't match exactly but bypass intended checks? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-compiler-v2/src/pipeline/lint_processor.rs] [Function: get_applicable_linter_pipeline()] [Iterator chain vulnerability] The flat_map operation (lines 68-73) chains multiple checker sources - can an attacker inject infinite iterators or extremely long checker lists to cause compilation hangs or memory exhaustion? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-compiler-v2/src/pipeline/lint_processor.rs] [Function: get_applicable_linter_pipeline()] [Type confusion] The get_stackless_bytecode_checkers() returns Box<dyn StacklessBytecodeChecker> trait objects - can an attacker provide checkers that implement the trait incorrectly, causing type confusion or memory corruption when check() is invoked? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-compiler-v2/src/pipeline/lint_processor.rs] [Function: get_applicable_linter_pipeline()] [Malicious checker injection] External checks come from options.external_checks (line 66) which are Arc<dyn ExternalChecks> - can an attacker inject checkers that report false negatives for security issues or silently corrupt compilation state? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-compiler-v2/src/pipeline/lint_processor.rs] [Function: get_applicable_linter_pipeline()] [Ordering vulnerability] The lint_skips are computed once (line 64) before filtering - if checker names change dynamically during iteration, can this create time-of-check-time-of-use issues where skipped checkers still execute? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-compiler-v2/src/pipeline/lint_processor.rs] [Function: get_applicable_linter_pipeline()] [Reference lifetime] The target parameter is borrowed (line 54) - if the returned checker boxes capture references to target, could this create dangling references when the target goes out of scope? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-compiler-v2/src/pipeline/lint_processor.rs] [Function: get_applicable_linter_pipeline()] [Collect allocation] The collect() on line 74 allocates a Vec - can extremely large checker lists cause OOM conditions or excessive memory consumption during compilation? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-compiler-v2/src/pipeline/lint_processor.rs] [Function: get_lint_skips()] [Attribute parsing vulnerability] The lint_skips_from_attributes() function (lines 82-86, 87-90) parses user-controlled attributes - can an attacker craft malicious attribute AST nodes that exploit parsing bugs to inject arbitrary checker names into the skip list? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-compiler-v2/src/pipeline/lint_processor.rs] [Function: get_lint_skips()] [Privilege escalation] Module-level lint skips (lines 82-86) and function-level skips (lines 87-90) are merged via chain() (line 92) - can an attacker use this merging to escalate module-level permissions or override function-specific security requirements? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-compiler-v2/src/pipeline/lint_processor.rs] [Function: get_lint_skips()] [Set manipulation] The BTreeSet::from_iter() on line 92 processes both module and function skips - can duplicate entries or hash collision attacks cause certain skips to be silently dropped, leading to unexpected checker execution? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-compiler-v2/src/pipeline/lint_processor.rs] [Function: get_lint_skips()] [Validation bypass] The known_checker_names are passed to lint_skips_from_attributes() for validation - if this validation is incomplete in lint_common.rs, can attackers specify skip directives for checkers that don't exist yet, preemptively disabling future security checks? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-compiler-v2/src/pipeline/lint_processor.rs] [Function: get_lint_skips()] [Iterator consumption] The into_iter() chains (line 92) consume both skip collections - are there race conditions where concurrent access to the same attributes could lead to inconsistent skip sets across multiple invocations? (Medium)
